M., as much of the real estates of Cyrus and Will jam Wheeler, Ira Smith, John Adam, Seth P. Beers, Isaac Wadhams, Calvin Collins, Forbes & Adams, Samual Maize. Eber Pe- ters, John M. West and Samuel Wright, non residents, and EIihu Frishie and Enoch Fay Tor residents as will be nect ssary to pay q Town Tax of said Town of Warren of five cents on the Dollar, on the assessment List of 1925 and legal cost.

 BENONI F. BEARDSLEY, Collector.

 Warren, Dec. 26, 4826 29

FHHHE residents and nen-rcsidcnts of the A town of Kent who are liable by law to pay taxes, are hereby notified that the sub scriber has received a warrant to collect town tax of them laid on the List of 1895, & will meet them at the Inn of Pho Mills on the first Monday of February, 1927 :; at the Inn of John w. McKoy on the second Mon day of February. 1927; and at the Inn of Wm. T. Hopson on the third Monday of Feb ruary, ls27 in said Kent, at each of said pla- ces at nine o'clock A. M. to receive said tax es. All those who neglect to pay at said dates must expect to pay the travelling fees allowed by law.

 HIRAM CONVERSE, Collector.

 Kent, Dec. @5, 1926. 29
COLLECTORS NOTICE.

ble, and can perceive no objection to mee- ting in this county, for the purpose Ot express sing an opinion respecting the prOpriety of caucus nominations, and of arranging the pre- iiminaries Ofa convention to be held after the next session of the general assembly, for the purpose of designating candidates for the then next election. It will then he understood that no legislative caucus is to be held; the can didates proposed by the convention will re- ceive the undivided support of the republican party; and thus the new mode Ofnomination will silently, and without the hazard of divis- ion, supersede the old.

 A REPUBLICAN ELEcToR.

 The subscribers give notice that they shall meet at the dwelling house of Samuel Church in said Bcthlem on the first Monday of Feb ruary and on the 9th day of June next at o'clock in the afternoon on each of said days, for the purpose of attending on the business of said appointment.

 DAVID BIRD, HERMANUS MARSHALL, cc"'"tS- NATHAN HAWLEY. "'O'''S'

to erect it if Intemperancc holds sway and palsies the energies of the land where will be the arm that is to wield the sword in her defence. It will have become weak and ener

 vated. this ruthless messenger of disease and woe will have trodden on the neck of our fal

 len country. But from these direful presages turn to the remedy, if indeed there be one :, and would call on all who are concerned in the navigation of this noble ship that they throw out signals of distress. l would call on every man in community if he has the interest of his country at heart, and would guard against the intrusion of this fell destroyer into his own family, that he use his utmost exertOn and influence that its ravages extend no far ther. OFFICE OF THE SATURDAY EvENING Posr,

 Philadelphia, Dec. 9, 1928.

 THE CASKET, or Fio,Cers of Literuture, Wit and Sentiment, which has had an uupre- cedented increase of patrons during the last six months, will, after the present volume is finished, contain. each number, forty octave pages, printed well. on small handsome type upon the finest paper, stitched and covered, and furnished to subscribers at the low price of Two Dollars and fifty cents per annum The Casket is collection from the choicest pieces of the Saturday Evening Post, made with a reference to the difference which should exist in the materials of weekly pa per, and those of monthly publication, the former ofcourse enriched with essays, poetry, anecdotes, and those set off by recital of the occurrences of the week. The latter can re- ceivc little value from mere detail of events, many of which would cease to be interestine before they were recorded.

 The vast quantity of matter crowded, by small type. and careful arrangement into the columns of every numbeF of the Saturday Evening Post, will in the course of q month. furnish the most ample materials from which to form an interesting and periodical work such as the Casket has been considered by it's
THE CASKET, IA OR FLOWERS OF, LITERATURE. WIT & SENTIMENT. FOR 1927.

partial Friends, and such as we intend. it skaH bc. Notwithstanding the fact, that the Casx- ct is but collection from the Saturday Eve ming Post, we confidently predict, and indeed we are sanctioned in the experience we aIrea- dy have, that it's most numerous patrons will be found among the subscribers to our weekly paper.-A large number of th0se who take the " Post" depend upon that paper for the news of the week---it is therefore read with avidity by almost every member of the family where t is received, and this general use frequently irjures its appearance so much as almost to render it unfit for the fiie, and fo. binding. The numbers too, by this general use, are not un- frequently lost, muiuated or entirely destroy ed, and the file thus broken.-The Casket is l calculated to prevent this inconvenience, and to furnish, al a very cheap price, all the useful | matter for which the weekly paper would be d"siTi,b.c when bound,-In thus giving a per- inanent form and select association to the choice pieces of our weekly contributors, it is confidently anticipated that new and success iul inducements will be hclG out for the exer- else of superior talent, and unusual care in our literary drpartment.-In addition to the l recommendation Of fneatnrss in the general ap- | pearance--and particular attention to the ty- geographical execution, it is our iptention fo enlbehish each number of the '' Casket" with | Lt'te AtliuSOhiS IECIA lHe UdDuS of some of the most distinguished artists of l the country. With these claims to patronage, the "CAs- ket'' will, as has been previously mentioned, be afforded to those who subscribe for that paper exclusively, at the low price of Se, 50 per year, subscription which it is confident 1 ty believed, is much lower than that of any other publication of similar character in this country-but to the hesubscribers of The Sat- 'trday Evening Post' "The Casket' will be furnished for S@,O0.

 The January number for 1897, will be em- beIlished with d portrait of the late venerable JOHN ADAMS, formerly President of the United States, one of Longacre's best engra- wings: also, a correct and beautiful view of FAIR MOUNT WATER WORKS, in the vicinity of Philadelphia besides, the first No. of the SCHOOL OF FLORA, being the commencement of regelar series of Treati- ses on Botany, illustrated with numererous cuts.

 Post-masters and publishers of papers who

 will interest themselves in obtaining subscri-

 bers, and he responsible for the subscription, shall be entitled to every sixth copy gratis Address.

 ATKINSON & ALEXANDER, Philadelphia.

 Persons wishing to subscribe, will please to send in their names by the first of the year, as there is DO doubt the demand for the work will be greatly increased, and therefose the possibility of being furnished with the Nos. from the beginning, will be rendered hlore doubtful. go

T1IlE Hon. Court of Probate for the dis A trict of Sharon, has assigned the 18th day of January 1927, at o'clock in the fore noon at the Probate Office in Salisbury for the settlement of the Administration accounts ot the Execctor of the Will and Testament of

 MORRIS S. STURGESS, late of Sharon in said district deceased, when and where all persons interested in said estate may appear and be heard.

 By order of Court.

 % JAY S. STURGESS, Erecutor
Norris s. Sturgess' Estate.

There is an immediate connection between matter and mind, as they unite and consti- tute man. Whatever impulse sets in motion the powers of the mind, is felt either directly or indirectly by the body; as on the contra ry, whatever causes affect the body, whether they he natural-as heat and cold, hunger and thirst, or whether they be health or decease, these operating directly in the body itself have a collateral effect in the mind, and tend either to make it elastic and happy, full of high hopes and jocund as the spring, or produce a despondency which prcys upon our happi- ness, and oftentimes, makes us feel as if we were outcasts from the favours of providence, and that our destiny was to be miserable. Onr happiness then must necessarily depend in the main on the situation of the body. In proportion as the latter is weighed down by any of those diseases which prove to us the frailty of our natures, the former is the sub .ject of restIessness and disquietude. Not but that the mind may, Independently ofthe body, engender and multiply its own troubles; it often does, and many sore wound does it infiictin itself; but now speak of those causes which commence acting on the body and are through the medium of the body made to op- crate oh the mind. The mutual dependence then of body and mind for the support and comfort of each other, makes it of the highest moment to take care about the introduction into either, ofany more trouble than is by ne- cessity caused from the constitution and con dition of our natures, and by events and cir cumstances beyond our controul. But many are the pains endured by our habits, and ma my thorn is made to rankle in our bosoms. planted there by our own hands.

 Customs and long cherished notions make many courses fashionable which courses are so many post roads on which thousands of the eager vOtarics of pleasure travel some to an early grave, others to premature old age; while others find themselves engrdled by circle of diseases which torture both body & lnind. It is of vast importance then that the mind be made to think in correct channels, & that the body be trained up to the exercise of whatever is necessary to the regular perform ance of its functions and the health of all its members. We prostrate the fairest the no- biest work of God, when by neglect, or in- temperance, we sow the seeds of dissolution in ourselyes--we make advances to our great est enemy, death, when we employ any of the emissaries which he sends to us On errands of destruction, and thousands of these emissa- are abroad in the world sucking up the juices of human happiness, and endeavouring with all their malignant cunning at the destruction ofthe human race. Already have they thrown a portentious gloom over this land of civili- zation and refinement, already has intempe- rance spread her sable mantle upon the bo- som of our country and when and how she is to dismantle herself God only knows. It must be ere long as it will have nipped the tenderest buds that put forth from the bosom of our families. This nation proudly vaunts herself on her physical strength and resources, while a disease turks within her veins nrure fa- tai than the pestiferous blasts of the Simeon, and more to be dreaded than fleets end armies. The attention of many has been called to this subject. It demands yigoHrous and decided measures. do not know that there is moral principle enough in the land to stay the tide of desolation; if there is not, legislative aid must be called in.

 There is but one alternative, either intem- perance or our national prosperity and per haps cur national existence, must cease. The men of former generation trained as they were to arms, their constitutions made vigor- ous and healthful by athletic sports and inured to toil and hardship in every possible shape. could mingle in scenes of debauchery and in- temperance and yet eke out long life but either from the peculiarity of our climate or some other natural cause, or from the degen- eracy of the present race of men from the physical strength and hardihood of their an- cestors, the process is now summary: and thousands of youth, the flower of our land & the hopes of their parents yearly fall before this sirocco, like the yellow leaves which the autumnal blast strows upon the health. This

 lS25.

NIT. i1ayne, rom the select commute to which was referred the bill '' to establish an uniform system of bankruptcy through out the United States, reported the same without amendment. The bill was made the order of the day for Tuesday the 26th Dec. The resolution offered on Monday by Mir. Johnson, of Kentucky, proposing an examination of sites, with a view to the establishment of National Armory on the Western waters, was ta- ken up. After. some discussion, 1t was laid on the table. #.

 In the House of Representives, the Va rious resolutions laid on the table yeSter- day, were adopted, with various modiGca- tions-except the resolution offered by MT. M Hatton, of Kentucky, relative to a National Armory at Horse Shoe Bend, which the House refused to consider.

 The House went into Conlmitte of the Whole on the bill to authorize the impor- tation of Brandy in casks of not less than fifteen gallons, which passed thro' the committee without amendment; but some discussion respecting its provisions arose in the House, which was cut short by successful motion to adjourn. Among the resolutions agreed to, was one from MT. Cook, instructing the Committee on Roads and Canals to inquire into the sub- ject of granting to the State of Illinois the lead made at Fever River, to aid in ope- ming canal from Lake Michigan to the Illinois river, and another offered by Mr. Mitchel, of South Carolina, instructiug the Committe on Naval Affairs to inquire into the expediency of appropriating annually $500, ,OOO to the gradual increase of the Navy.

 Resolutions were laid on the table by Nlr. Halle, of Mississippi, calling on the Secretary of War for information of any encroachment by white persons on the

 lands granted to the Choctaw Indians; by MT. Moore, of Alabama, asking of the same Department information as to the direction in which the Typographical and and Civil Engineers have been employed under the act of 1924 appropriating So,- 900 dollars for surveys, ,&c'

 Wednesday,, Dec. 2O.-In the Senate, the resolution submitted on monday by Mir. Johnson, of Kentucky, relative to the es- tablislment of an Armory on the Western waters, was taken into consideration, and after some amendments had been offered, it was laid on the table.

 In the House of Represcntivcs, some discussion took place on a motion of the committee on Military Affairs to be dschar- ged from the further consideration of the Georgia militia claims which motion was opposed with success. The bill to provide for the importation of brandy in casks of not less than 15 gallons, was postponed until Tuesday next. The bill to provide for the payment of Interpreters fees in the United States courts in Louisiana went through committee, where it was a. mended, so as to extend its provisions to all the states and territories. Several pri- vate bills were also acted on; and the res- olution offered on Tuesday by Mr. Halle, of Mississippi, relative to encroaChments on the Choctaw lands, was adopted, will, an amendment offered by Mir. Conway, of Arkansas.

 A resolution submitted on Tuesday by Mir. Edwards, of Pennsylvania, was con- sidered and agreed to, which resolution directs the Secretary of War to communi- cate to the House the result of the survey made in pursuance of the act of the last session, directing survey of the public pfGlS at SHCStCI, OH ilNCI ACIdWdiCs in order to determine the expediency of Aaccepting the cession thereof made by the State of Pennsylvania, and the expense of repairing the same. Tuesday Dec. 21.-In the Senate, MT. John M'Kinley, appointed by the legisla- ture of Alabama to fill the vacancy occa- stoned by the death of Henry Chambers, appeared and took his seat.

 A Bill passed to be engrossed to allow Francis Larche of New Orleans, $500, for negro slave pressed into the service of the United States, in the army under General Jackson, and killed by cannon ball.

 In the House, resolutions were adopted, by which the members ofthe house to tes- tify their respect for the memory of three members of the house who died during the | late recess, agree to were crape for month, viz. Robt. P. Henry and Col. James Johnson, of Kentucky, and HenryP. Wil- son of Pennsylvania.

 No.other business of interest was trans acted in the House this day.

 Friday Dec. 22. In the Senate, the bill for the relief of Lieut.. Mckeeyer, all lowing him further remuneration for ex- penSeS incurred bv him in prosecuting to |
18th CoNGREss........2d SESSION.

G}@For the greater accommodation of several towns in the county, and with the hope of extending the circulation of our paper, we shall hereafter issue the County Post on Friday, instead of Tuesday, of each week. Our next number will of course be publish cd on the 12th inste Our present subscri- bcrs will be able to receive their papers as early after publication, as they have hereto fore received them.

MT Johnson, of Kentucky, from the Se- i lect Committee on the bill for G6OIisking l Imprisonment for debt, reported the bill with amendments.

 Att o'clock the Senate went into the consideration of Executive business. In the House, a brief discussion was e.

 icited by a resolution offered by Mir. Cook, the object of which was to obtain some relief for the purchasers ofland who, not having completed their payments, have incurred the penalty of forfeiture of the lands. His resolutions asked for the ap- pointment of Select Committee to in- quire into the expediency of exchanging these certificates for scrip, which the hold CTS might dispose of for other lands.

 The resolution was amended, on motion of Mr. Campbell, so as tn be referred to the Committee on Public Lands.

 From the papers of the day we learn that the small pox, that most loatIAsome of all di- seases, is again making its appearance ia our country. More than sixty cases have occur red at Staten Island, N. Y. about twenty of which have proved fatal. A number of cases have also occurred at New Haven. The Re gister mentions three or four cases in North Brandford. The Mercury says this disease prevails to an alarming degree in the town of Bolton. Several other towns are also visited | by this terrible scourge. Providence has pla- l ced within the reach of every person an effect ua safe-g guard against this baleful disease; & he who refuses to employ the remedy for Himself and his children does an injury which may be lrreparable. The Mercury asks, G. Where is Dr. Fansher ?" We answer, he has been in this county with very little benefit to commit nity, and an actual loss to himself; the people having been too busily engaged about their 'iarms and merchandise 3 to profit by his skill

 and experience. He is now in Vermont, where We trust the prudence of the citizens will amply remunerate him for his labours and expense for the public good.

 Trials for M,uder.-On the goth and elst ults. the trial of Winslow Curtis came on, for the murder of Capt. Edward Selfridge, cap tain of the schooner Fairy. On the last day the jury returned a verdict ofguilty. Charles | Merchant was previously tried for the murder 1 fir. r. Jenkins, mate of the same schooner, and found guilty. On the 23d the criminals received sentence of death, aud are to be exc cuted on the first ofFebruary. A Boston pa per says, "After the sentence ,whicl was pro- nounced by Judge Story in most solemn and impressive lnanner, the prisoners gave ut terance to their feelings in the most horrid imprecations ofvengence and malignity upon the Judge, the attorney general, the witnes- ses, and the souls ofthe victims they had been convicted of murdering, in language too shocking for repetition. Such scene of de- pravity and hardihood, it is presumed, has never before, in this country at least, been witnessed in court ofjustice.''

 But little business has been transacted at Washington since the 24th ult. up to our last l dates. Levees and parties of pleasure occu pied the whole attention of our HOnourables during the first week of Christmas. This ] suspension of Congressional news gives the knowing ones an opportunity to indulge in cOnjectures relative to the difficulties between this country and England. Some pretend to see specks of war, and others predict the complete overthrow of the administration, as they are disposed to visit upon MT. Adams and the cabinet the whole blame ofthe loss of the VI. trade. For ourselves we can see no other signs of war than in a belief that it will materially benefit the |" mother country" in hCA PitSCHt uisuSSSs to cILEuOy puTuOU OI her suffering surplus population in making conquests, Or in attempting to humble the pride and ambition of her enterprising quan- dam daughter. Whether the late act of Par lament and subsequent conduct, be the pre- cursor for picking quarrel. time will deter mine.-And as for the ruin of the great re- publican family, at the bead of which is J.. Q. Adams, II. Clay, Sc. we have no fears. The good sense and patriotism of this cOuntry,wi! never yield an undoubted right, alright toper- feet reciprocity in trade, for the '' boon," as Mir. Secretary Canning calls the w. I. trade; neither will the unjust demands ofthe British cabinet effect the popularity of the adminis- tration, or destroy the confidence which the people have reposed in it. 0}@For the greater accommodation of several

 towns in the county, and with the hope of

 extending the circulation of our paper, we

 shall hereafter issue the County Post on

 Friday, instead of Tuesday, of each week.

 Our next number will of course be publish

 cd on the l2th insts Our present subscri- 1

 bcrs will be able to receive their papers as

 early after publication, as they have hereto

 fore received them. 0T@The Slips in the Episcopal Church in

 this village will be rented for one year on

full articles.article:
There is an immediate connection between matter and mind, as they unite and consti- tute man. Whatever impulse sets in motion the powers of the mind, is felt either directly or indirectly by the body; as on the contra ry, whatever causes affect the body, whether they he natural-as heat and cold, hunger and thirst, or whether they be health or decease, these operating directly in the body itself have a collateral effect in the mind, and tend either to make it elastic and happy, full of high hopes and jocund as the spring, or produce a despondency which prcys upon our happi- ness, and oftentimes, makes us feel as if we were outcasts from the favours of providence, and that our destiny was to be miserable. Onr happiness then must necessarily depend in the main on the situation of the body. In proportion as the latter is weighed down by any of those diseases which prove to us the frailty of our natures, the former is the sub .ject of restIessness and disquietude. Not but that the mind may, Independently ofthe body, engender and multiply its own troubles; it often does, and many sore wound does it infiictin itself; but now speak of those causes which commence acting on the body and are through the medium of the body made to op- crate oh the mind. The mutual dependence then of body and mind for the support and comfort of each other, makes it of the highest moment to take care about the introduction into either, ofany more trouble than is by ne- cessity caused from the constitution and con dition of our natures, and by events and cir cumstances beyond our controul. But many are the pains endured by our habits, and ma my thorn is made to rankle in our bosoms. planted there by our own hands.

 Customs and long cherished notions make many courses fashionable which courses are so many post roads on which thousands of the eager vOtarics of pleasure travel some to an early grave, others to premature old age; while others find themselves engrdled by circle of diseases which torture both body & lnind. It is of vast importance then that the mind be made to think in correct channels, & that the body be trained up to the exercise of whatever is necessary to the regular perform ance of its functions and the health of all its members. We prostrate the fairest the no- biest work of God, when by neglect, or in- temperance, we sow the seeds of dissolution in ourselyes--we make advances to our great est enemy, death, when we employ any of the emissaries which he sends to us On errands of destruction, and thousands of these emissa- are abroad in the world sucking up the juices of human happiness, and endeavouring with all their malignant cunning at the destruction ofthe human race. Already have they thrown a portentious gloom over this land of civili- zation and refinement, already has intempe- rance spread her sable mantle upon the bo- som of our country and when and how she is to dismantle herself God only knows. It must be ere long as it will have nipped the tenderest buds that put forth from the bosom of our families. This nation proudly vaunts herself on her physical strength and resources, while a disease turks within her veins nrure fa- tai than the pestiferous blasts of the Simeon, and more to be dreaded than fleets end armies. The attention of many has been called to this subject. It demands yigoHrous and decided measures. do not know that there is moral principle enough in the land to stay the tide of desolation; if there is not, legislative aid must be called in.

 There is but one alternative, either intem- perance or our national prosperity and per haps cur national existence, must cease. The men of former generation trained as they were to arms, their constitutions made vigor- ous and healthful by athletic sports and inured to toil and hardship in every possible shape. could mingle in scenes of debauchery and in- temperance and yet eke out long life but either from the peculiarity of our climate or some other natural cause, or from the degen- eracy of the present race of men from the physical strength and hardihood of their an- cestors, the process is now summary: and thousands of youth, the flower of our land & the hopes of their parents yearly fall before this sirocco, like the yellow leaves which the autumnal blast strows upon the health. This
GFThe Slips in the Episcopal Church in this village will be rented for one year on Saturday, the 18th inst. at the Church. Sale to commence at 10 o'clock, AM.

full articles.headline: 18th CoNGREss........2d SESSION.
full articles.article:
NIT. i1ayne, rom the select commute to which was referred the bill '' to establish an uniform system of bankruptcy through out the United States, reported the same without amendment. The bill was made the order of the day for Tuesday the 26th Dec. The resolution offered on Monday by Mir. Johnson, of Kentucky, proposing an examination of sites, with a view to the establishment of National Armory on the Western waters, was ta- ken up. After. some discussion, 1t was laid on the table. #.

 In the House of Representives, the Va rious resolutions laid on the table yeSter- day, were adopted, with various modiGca- tions-except the resolution offered by MT. M Hatton, of Kentucky, relative to a National Armory at Horse Shoe Bend, which the House refused to consider.

 The House went into Conlmitte of the Whole on the bill to authorize the impor- tation of Brandy in casks of not less than fifteen gallons, which passed thro' the committee without amendment; but some discussion respecting its provisions arose in the House, which was cut short by successful motion to adjourn. Among the resolutions agreed to, was one from MT. Cook, instructing the Committee on Roads and Canals to inquire into the sub- ject of granting to the State of Illinois the lead made at Fever River, to aid in ope- ming canal from Lake Michigan to the Illinois river, and another offered by Mr. Mitchel, of South Carolina, instructiug the Committe on Naval Affairs to inquire into the expediency of appropriating annually $500, ,OOO to the gradual increase of the Navy.

 Resolutions were laid on the table by Nlr. Halle, of Mississippi, calling on the Secretary of War for information of any encroachment by white persons on the

 lands granted to the Choctaw Indians; by MT. Moore, of Alabama, asking of the same Department information as to the direction in which the Typographical and and Civil Engineers have been employed under the act of 1924 appropriating So,- 900 dollars for surveys, ,&c'

 Wednesday,, Dec. 2O.-In the Senate, the resolution submitted on monday by Mir. Johnson, of Kentucky, relative to the es- tablislment of an Armory on the Western waters, was taken into consideration, and after some amendments had been offered, it was laid on the table.

 In the House of Represcntivcs, some discussion took place on a motion of the committee on Military Affairs to be dschar- ged from the further consideration of the Georgia militia claims which motion was opposed with success. The bill to provide for the importation of brandy in casks of not less than 15 gallons, was postponed until Tuesday next. The bill to provide for the payment of Interpreters fees in the United States courts in Louisiana went through committee, where it was a. mended, so as to extend its provisions to all the states and territories. Several pri- vate bills were also acted on; and the res- olution offered on Tuesday by Mr. Halle, of Mississippi, relative to encroaChments on the Choctaw lands, was adopted, will, an amendment offered by Mir. Conway, of Arkansas.

 A resolution submitted on Tuesday by Mir. Edwards, of Pennsylvania, was con- sidered and agreed to, which resolution directs the Secretary of War to communi- cate to the House the result of the survey made in pursuance of the act of the last session, directing survey of the public pfGlS at SHCStCI, OH ilNCI ACIdWdiCs in order to determine the expediency of Aaccepting the cession thereof made by the State of Pennsylvania, and the expense of repairing the same. Tuesday Dec. 21.-In the Senate, MT. John M'Kinley, appointed by the legisla- ture of Alabama to fill the vacancy occa- stoned by the death of Henry Chambers, appeared and took his seat.

 A Bill passed to be engrossed to allow Francis Larche of New Orleans, $500, for negro slave pressed into the service of the United States, in the army under General Jackson, and killed by cannon ball.

 In the House, resolutions were adopted, by which the members ofthe house to tes- tify their respect for the memory of three members of the house who died during the | late recess, agree to were crape for month, viz. Robt. P. Henry and Col. James Johnson, of Kentucky, and HenryP. Wil- son of Pennsylvania.

 No.other business of interest was trans acted in the House this day.

 Friday Dec. 22. In the Senate, the bill for the relief of Lieut.. Mckeeyer, all lowing him further remuneration for ex- penSeS incurred bv him in prosecuting to |

G}@For the greater accommodation of several towns in the county, and with the hope of extending the circulation of our paper, we shall hereafter issue the County Post on Friday, instead of Tuesday, of each week. Our next number will of course be publish cd on the 12th inste Our present subscri- bcrs will be able to receive their papers as early after publication, as they have hereto fore received them.

MT Johnson, of Kentucky, from the Se- i lect Committee on the bill for G6OIisking l Imprisonment for debt, reported the bill with amendments.

 Att o'clock the Senate went into the consideration of Executive business. In the House, a brief discussion was e.

 icited by a resolution offered by Mir. Cook, the object of which was to obtain some relief for the purchasers ofland who, not having completed their payments, have incurred the penalty of forfeiture of the lands. His resolutions asked for the ap- pointment of Select Committee to in- quire into the expediency of exchanging these certificates for scrip, which the hold CTS might dispose of for other lands.

 The resolution was amended, on motion of Mr. Campbell, so as tn be referred to the Committee on Public Lands.

 From the papers of the day we learn that the small pox, that most loatIAsome of all di- seases, is again making its appearance ia our country. More than sixty cases have occur red at Staten Island, N. Y. about twenty of which have proved fatal. A number of cases have also occurred at New Haven. The Re gister mentions three or four cases in North Brandford. The Mercury says this disease prevails to an alarming degree in the town of Bolton. Several other towns are also visited | by this terrible scourge. Providence has pla- l ced within the reach of every person an effect ua safe-g guard against this baleful disease; & he who refuses to employ the remedy for Himself and his children does an injury which may be lrreparable. The Mercury asks, G. Where is Dr. Fansher ?" We answer, he has been in this county with very little benefit to commit nity, and an actual loss to himself; the people having been too busily engaged about their 'iarms and merchandise 3 to profit by his skill

 and experience. He is now in Vermont, where We trust the prudence of the citizens will amply remunerate him for his labours and expense for the public good.

 Trials for M,uder.-On the goth and elst ults. the trial of Winslow Curtis came on, for the murder of Capt. Edward Selfridge, cap tain of the schooner Fairy. On the last day the jury returned a verdict ofguilty. Charles | Merchant was previously tried for the murder 1 fir. r. Jenkins, mate of the same schooner, and found guilty. On the 23d the criminals received sentence of death, aud are to be exc cuted on the first ofFebruary. A Boston pa per says, "After the sentence ,whicl was pro- nounced by Judge Story in most solemn and impressive lnanner, the prisoners gave ut terance to their feelings in the most horrid imprecations ofvengence and malignity upon the Judge, the attorney general, the witnes- ses, and the souls ofthe victims they had been convicted of murdering, in language too shocking for repetition. Such scene of de- pravity and hardihood, it is presumed, has never before, in this country at least, been witnessed in court ofjustice.''

 But little business has been transacted at Washington since the 24th ult. up to our last l dates. Levees and parties of pleasure occu pied the whole attention of our HOnourables during the first week of Christmas. This ] suspension of Congressional news gives the knowing ones an opportunity to indulge in cOnjectures relative to the difficulties between this country and England. Some pretend to see specks of war, and others predict the complete overthrow of the administration, as they are disposed to visit upon MT. Adams and the cabinet the whole blame ofthe loss of the VI. trade. For ourselves we can see no other signs of war than in a belief that it will materially benefit the |" mother country" in hCA PitSCHt uisuSSSs to cILEuOy puTuOU OI her suffering surplus population in making conquests, Or in attempting to humble the pride and ambition of her enterprising quan- dam daughter. Whether the late act of Par lament and subsequent conduct, be the pre- cursor for picking quarrel. time will deter mine.-And as for the ruin of the great re- publican family, at the bead of which is J.. Q. Adams, II. Clay, Sc. we have no fears. The good sense and patriotism of this cOuntry,wi! never yield an undoubted right, alright toper- feet reciprocity in trade, for the '' boon," as Mir. Secretary Canning calls the w. I. trade; neither will the unjust demands ofthe British cabinet effect the popularity of the adminis- tration, or destroy the confidence which the people have reposed in it. 0}@For the greater accommodation of several
